case_data.chief_complaint: Recurrent kidney stones, generalized bone pain, and fatigue for 8 months
case_data.initial_presentation: A 42-year-old government clerk from Lucknow presents with a third episode of renal colic in 8 months, along with progressive generalized bone pain (especially in the lower back and legs), easy fatigability, and constipation. He was found to have a serum calcium of 13.2 mg/dL during his last emergency visit for renal colic.

stages.info: Three episodes of left-sided renal colic over 8 months; passed one stone spontaneously, required lithotripsy once. Diffuse bone pain for 6 months — worse in lower limbs and lower back, progressive, not relieved by OTC analgesics. Constipation for 4 months (passes stool every 3-4 days). Increased thirst and polyuria (drinks ~4-5 liters/day). Decreased appetite, occasional nausea, 4 kg weight loss. Difficulty concentrating at work, feels 'mentally foggy,' low mood. No history of malignancy, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, or prolonged immobilization. Not taking any calcium, vitamin D, antacids, lithium, or thiazide diuretics. No family history of kidney stones or endocrine disorders. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol use. Diet: Predominantly vegetarian.

Mild dehydration (dry oral mucosa). No pallor, icterus, or lymphadenopathy. No neck swelling or palpable thyroid nodule — however, careful palpation reveals a firm, non-tender 1.5 cm nodule just inferior and posterior to the left lower pole of thyroid. Musculoskeletal: Diffuse bony tenderness on palpation of tibia and lumbar spine. Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty rising from squatting — positive Gower-like sign). No joint swelling. Abdomen: Mild left renal angle tenderness. No hepatosplenomegaly. Neuropsychiatric: Slightly slow mentation, no focal neurological deficits. No band keratopathy on gross inspection.

Serum calcium: 13.4 mg/dL (normal 8.5-10.5). Ionized calcium: 1.78 mmol/L (elevated). Serum phosphorus: 1.8 mg/dL (low; normal 2.5-4.5). Intact PTH: 285 pg/mL (markedly elevated; normal 10-65). Alkaline phosphatase: 420 U/L (elevated; normal 44-147). 24-hour urine calcium: 480 mg/day (elevated; normal <250). Serum 25-OH Vitamin D: 12 ng/mL (deficient — common in India, can exacerbate PHPT). Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL (mildly elevated). Serum albumin: 3.8 g/dL (corrected calcium still elevated). CT KUB: Bilateral renal calculi (left 8 mm mid-ureteric, right 5 mm lower pole, both calcium-containing). X-ray hands: Subperiosteal resorption along radial aspect of middle phalanges. X-ray skull: 'Salt and pepper' appearance (osteitis fibrosa cystica). DEXA scan: T-score -3.1 at lumbar spine (osteoporosis), -2.8 at distal 1/3 radius. Tc-99m Sestamibi scan: Focal increased tracer uptake persisting in delayed images at left inferior parathyroid region, consistent with parathyroid adenoma. Ultrasound neck: 1.6 cm hypoechoic nodule posterior to left inferior thyroid pole with feeding vessel (polar vessel sign). TSH: 4.2 mIU/L (normal). ECG: Shortened QT interval.

case_data.diagnosis: Primary hyperparathyroidism due to left inferior parathyroid adenoma with symptomatic hypercalcemia (bones, stones, groans, and psychic moans), complicated by concurrent vitamin D deficiency
learning_points: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is characterized by elevated calcium with inappropriately elevated or non-suppressed PTH — this combination is the diagnostic hallmark. Simultaneously elevated calcium + PTH essentially clinches the diagnosis.

The classic clinical tetrad is 'bones (osteitis fibrosa cystica, fractures), stones (nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis), abdominal groans (constipation, pancreatitis, peptic ulcer), and psychic moans (depression, confusion, fatigue).' Indian patients tend to present with more severe skeletal and renal disease compared to Western populations.

Concurrent vitamin D deficiency (extremely common in India) can mask the severity of hypercalcemia in PHPT and paradoxically worsen bone disease by further stimulating PTH. Vitamin D should be cautiously repleted preoperatively while monitoring calcium closely.

Tc-99m Sestamibi parathyroid scan combined with neck ultrasound is the standard preoperative localization strategy. Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy with intraoperative PTH monitoring is the treatment of choice. Post-surgery, watch for 'hungry bone syndrome' — severe hypocalcemia due to rapid bone remineralization.
case_data.atypical_features: This case is challenging because: (1) The coexistent vitamin D deficiency (very common in Indian vegetarian population) complicates the biochemical picture — phosphorus is very low and ALP very high, suggesting severe skeletal involvement amplified by vitamin D deficiency on top of PHPT; (2) The mildly elevated creatinine raises the question of whether this is primary or secondary/tertiary hyperparathyroidism from renal disease, requiring careful reasoning; (3) The patient presents with the full 'bones, stones, groans, moans' phenotype which is now more commonly seen in India than in Western countries where PHPT is detected incidentally — students must recognize this classic but increasingly rare full-blown presentation; (4) The hypertension is an underappreciated association with PHPT that may confuse the clinical picture.
